commentText: In the film industry, this has always been the big barrier to entry. You can't get a crew job unless you are in the union, and you can't get into the union without being an employee on a show or a movie. That's what kept me from being a cameraman on Wheel of Fortune, the producer saw me shooting a 1-off seminar on the Sony backlot and offered me the job but I wasn't in the Local 600. The only sector of the business where you don't need to be in a union is post-production, so that's where I ended up, and yes, the first dozen or so movies and TV shows I worked on (including some major ones on Comedy Central) were for free and I had to learn the hard way what "deferred payment" meant (it means free).

commentText: Of course AI will greatly disrupt economic models, and there may be universal basic income. There are many speakers who talk about that, but nobody is providing the public with much needed deeper answers: Once we have AGI, are most people going to get fired and replaced by robots? If so, will the owners of the robot-factories get insanely rich? Is there going to be mass poverty due to all the layoffs? If there is mass poverty, there will be no purchasing power, and so wouldn't the economy collapse? And so even those rich owners of robo-factories will fail as well? Just where will the money for the universal basic income come from? Is it from taxes on those massively profitable robo-factories? Just how exactly will this new economic model work?

commentText: As someone working in a similar space, his view is very similar to how I would judge current and future risks. One thing I would disagree with is AI replacing all work. AGI can more easily replace knowledge-based work that can be done mostly on the computer. But for manual labor, it requires robots as agents to act through. So far, no robot is even close to being as versatile as a human being and also scaling physical objects like robots provides less savings from an economic perspective. That doesn't mean it won't happen, but that means when talking about future scenarios AI alone without more progress in robotics will not replace all work humans can do.

commentText: The problem is that it is very challenging to detect exactly when a person is displaced by AI and Identify when to disperse compensation. CEOs are incentivized to replace or restructure as stealthily as possible as they quietly let go of staff and force their best performers to pick up the slack with AI tools. There are also many people *today* with invisible AI unemployment, like digital artists who do commissions or other professions like python devs from fiverr. At the end of the day, our society treats all homeless people the same, it won't be super clear exactly how much displacement happens from AI and Americans think helping thy neighbor is communist... So, we will likely need to have 5x-10x increase in hunger/homelessness in the US before either party even acknowledges the issue. We will have a massive humanitarian crisis and come out with leftist FDR-like policy changes by the end of it.

commentText: This won‚Äôt happen, because corporations are not outside of the social contract. Society doesn‚Äôt exist for corporations to make endless profit. Rather society exists to protect all human beings interests equally and preventing it from dissolving into the Hobbesian view of the absolute state of nature, open,(everyone at each other‚Äôs necks with no laws governing us.). Many philosophers and thinkers have written about how human beings have the right to revolt when society veers too far away from the social contract. It appears that by even questioning the possibility of a few corporations utilizing AI technologies to deprive the vast majority of human beings of their jobs and livelihoods, they are already intrinsically veering out of that boundary of the social contract. I advise them to think very hard and long about the inevitable consequences of following through with that.

commentText: I've worked in IT for decades and I saw this process when outsourcing took off and work was wholesale sent offshore (for cost improvements of course). The opportunity pool shrunk and as skills that had been in demand became commoditised there was downward pressure on wages as well. I saw large tech firms shrink their graduate intake programs while simultaneously scaling back the active upskilling and training of their existing workers (e.g. train yourself in your own time after hours). This is like that on steroids - it is a simultaneous race to find efficiency and cut costs and it is all being done using AI as a potential enabler but to what end ? The workforce and the education system cannot keep up and we could have a sudden generation of people who were highly motivated to position themselves for a future workplace that just doesn't want or need them - fraught times ahead I think...

commentText: The Gen Z experience:  - Graduate from high school in the midst of a pandemic (your graduation was almost certainly virtual) - Go to college (where a significant part of your college years was in front of a laptop) - Graduate with tens of thousands of dollars in debt - Can't get a job to pay off said debt and can‚Äôt get a job in the field you studied (or in any field) - Work minimum wage in order to BARELY get by - Live with your parents - Can't afford an apartment (don‚Äôt even think about ever buying a house) - Can't get a date because you‚Äôre too poor or you can't afford it - Have little to no friends because no one has the time to hang out - Get called ‚Äòlazy and entitled‚Äô by boomers and Gen X-ers  - Realize nothing matters no matter how hard you try or work, almost every common thing your parents had when they were younger is now unobtainable for you - You develop thoughts of üíÄ-ing yourself - You isolate yourself from society and spend all day in your moms basement playing video games to escape reality - You get addicted to porn to relieve the stress and anxiety that‚Äôs making your life difficult - You‚Äôre probably using drugs to numb the pain - You start to develop mental illness (as if you haven‚Äôt already developed it at this point) because the job market is destroying your mental health - Become another person in this generation, lost and forgotten  All while older people, employers and politicians wonder why Gen Z doesn't want to work or can't hold a job, are not dating or getting married, are not having babies, are socially inept, more than half are mentally unfit and a lot more are physically unfit, and a great sense of nihilism is sweeping the generation.   It was a losing battle before it even began. Gen Z was fucked the moment Covid came and destroyed everyone‚Äôs lives.

commentText: I've had many jobs in the past, so my resume is filled with experience, but as I have a disability, applying for a new one because previous ones were either seasonal or right before COVID hit as I was 17 and ending high school. I get so many chances with interviews, but when they hear "I have a disability," I already know in their mind that they're thinking, "This guy's a liability in our workforce. We shouldn't hire him." I don't blame them, but I don't see it fair game being the outcome was quite the ordeal. Gen Z are literal slaves to the economy. We want to work, but how can we when seeing barely any openings are given? Our depleting psyche of burn out, depression, anxiety, stress, etc. is always scoffed at and we're always said to be the "Lazy Generation or the "Snowflake Generation."  Whenever I hear an elderly say, "Back in my day, I was able to easily get this job, so why can't you do the same?" I'm like, "Because back in your day, you were given hope in society by people who spoke highly about it and actually got through with their promises, and an easier job market than ours." The system has changed. It's rare to hear Boomers to have some empathy towards us, but the majority see us as just the worst.       I'm just tired to complain to politicians and businesses who are too greedy and lazy to see that they're one of the main attributes this world is eroding to the downgrade to society.

videoTitle: The Brutal Reality of the Tech Job Market
videoDescription: The tech job market right now is brutal. Layoffs, endless applications, and constant rejections. It feels impossible to land an offer.
commentText: I retired from the IT industry after getting training through the military, two CISCO cert schools, some cybersecurity. I applied to every IT job in the state and only got a couple interviews with no jobs. I learned that I should just create my own company. The stability of employment, even if you're broke, is way better than constantly trying to shift focus to appease meaningless entry level jobs. After doing my own thing, I am now creating c++ apps, have hired some work out, and have attracted new job offers (sorry but I'm going for gold now). Pursue your craft and jobs will become a side hustle to earn some cash.

Companies are exaggerating "AI Productivity" so they can explain to shareholders that they're laying people off for that reason, not due to having a bad quarter. Even among Senior Devs, the only ones I know landing jobs right now are finding them through personal networks.

videoTitle: The Brutal Reality of the Tech Job Market
videoDescription: The tech job market right now is brutal. Layoffs, endless applications, and constant rejections. It feels impossible to land an offer.
commentText: I've come to the conclusion that I no longer want to chase after a language or framework. This changes all the time. I've also decided that I will no longer subject myself to being treated like a commodity at a cattle auction. In the end, all of this is designed to make you accept doing more for less. I think at some point we give in and accept unrealistic things because the "market demands it," or the influencer you follow or the group of followers in the bubble you're in dictates that this is the culture, technology, or method to be adopted. Yes, I went through a financial setback and had to accept working in other segments. But that didn't kill my desire to work with software. Today, I think the path is to work as an entrepreneur and consultant for small businesses, creating solutions for the region you live in or where you can work without creating a burden on your life. Another mistake I see is the industrialization of the IT workforce. We didn't start that way; we started in a garage or on a small project; we're not cattle.

videoTitle: The Brutal Reality of the Tech Job Market
videoDescription: The tech job market right now is brutal. Layoffs, endless applications, and constant rejections. It feels impossible to land an offer.
commentText: I worked in tech for 45 years in several roles. When I started, ‚ÄúBeing in computers.‚Äù, was like saying you were a Wizard in a tower. Your job was mysterious and magical and few others were in the industry competing for these enchanted positions. I retired a few years ago.  Nowadays, computer techs are a commodity and the perception is of an office worker. You are disposable and can be replaced in days from thousands of other candidates in your field. You‚Äôre no more important than a file clerk.  I worked through the tech industry‚Äôs best years and retired (age 60) at the tail end of that time.  Best of luck but it‚Äôs going to be a crap shoot and the jobs are pretty harsh.

commentText: I'm sorry the market is so brutal.  I would suggest, in the meantime, code your own apps for sale in the app store.  Doing this will achieve a few powerful things: (1) keep your skills fresh, (2) create something to show off, (3) potentially make some good money on the sale of your apps, and (4) keep your mind sharp, fresh.  You can also use this time to achieve certifications.  At the end of the day, give major consideration in the idea of working for yourself, building your own solutions.

videoTitle: The Brutal Reality of the Tech Job Market

commentText: The tech market isn't cooked, SWE jobs are cooked.  Lots of people don't realize there's so many other technical jobs out there to apply for. Look into Solution Engineer/Solutions Consultant roles, or Implementation Consultant, or Integration Specialist.  I went the implementation Consultant route, my current role only had 100 applicants in 2 weeks, meanwhile SWE jobs get 1000 applicants in 2 days.  I know it's easy to feel doomed but there are sooo many paths out there guys. I wouldn't even be surprised if I find myself as a SWE one day.

videoTitle: AI and the Future of Work
videoDescription: This event was recorded live on October 7, 2025. Artificial Intelligence is developing at breakneck speed, causing much anxiety ...
commentText: ‚ÄãI want to comment only on the part about how Artificial Intelligence is changing the job market, as you asked. ‚ÄãThe experts are right to be worried. The most important point they bring up is that many companies plan to use AI to take more and more tasks away from humans. ‚ÄãBut the worry shouldn't just be about "losing your job." The real problem is the value of your work. ‚ÄãA good salary was always safe because your skill was rare (hard to find). Now, AI makes that skill easy to find (abundant). What the machine does for free is worth very little when you do it. ‚ÄãThis is why your profession is going through Wage Compression. ‚ÄãThe solution is not just "using AI" to be faster. The solution is to pick a side in the market's new rule: ‚ÄãThe Machine's Boss: You tell the AI what it must do and what the goal is. You control the system. ‚ÄãThe Machine's Worker: You only do what the AI orders, like the example of the surgeon who becomes the machine's "steady hand". ‚ÄãIf you only follow the machine's orders, your value drops a lot. Your safety is in being the Boss.

videoTitle: AI and the Future of Work
videoDescription: This event was recorded live on October 7, 2025. Artificial Intelligence is developing at breakneck speed, causing much anxiety ...
commentText: I think the clearest enunciation of the real state of 'AI' and its dangers were by Zeynep Tufekci - although she claimed that LLMs work best with verifiable fields, such as coding. In fact, coding is just like the electrician example she used. The faults are hidden, plausible, and hard to find. There is no verification system right now - especially not the AI ones - that can find them all. And if testing does reveal a fault in outputs, finding where it resides (and working out how to fix it) are time consuming. For more specific detail, check out the MERT study on productivity harm using Claude - and note how even though coders thought they were more productive using generated code, they were less productive than similar coders not using the LLM.

commentText: Professor Chen‚Äôs analysis appears markedly Americophile, privileging U.S. capitalist models and strategic narratives while overlooking the fact that China‚Äôs industrial ascent has relied more heavily on European engineering partnerships and Franco-German production ecosystems than on American benevolence.  It seems Professor Chen has also adopted certain American manners. His opening remarks about Dr Jeffrey Sachs struck me as unnecessarily dismissive, particularly given Dr Sachs‚Äôs stature as both guest and world-renowned statesman.   Academic courtesy demands deference to invited speakers, especially one who has contributed so deeply to global development discourse. The tone at the outset reflected more of an American talk-show sparring style than the civility one expects of a university platform.  It was, in that sense, a disappointing moment for HKU Business School ‚Äî but an unqualified triumph for Dr Sachs, whose measured and eloquent address reminded the audience of China‚Äôs extraordinary civilisational continuity and the constructive possibilities of its future.

Countless chief executives, streamers, and half of LinkedIn keep telling people to start their own business. Yet human resources seems to hate it when you actually do. commentText: Every time there's an economic slowdown, companies stop hiring and blame "poorly skilled" employees. The moment the economy starts growing again, they hire regardless of whether the candidate is a total fit. If you need and want a workforce and can't find it, you just need to train them yourselves‚Äîit has happened many times before, and it will happen again. Not hiring, and consequently putting the remaining team under stress and overworking them, is the worse choice, in my opinion. I led a team (and was part of many in the earlier years of my career) - now I'm retired - and I would have rather gone the extra mile to train someone with the perspective of future relief/support than to wait for someone to magically appear after years. I'm sorry, as I usually appreciate your content, but in this case, it seems to me that you've missed the point of the issue and joined a narrative typical of some entrepreneurs, perhaps because it's easy to adopt

commentText: What worked for an old guy who just retired from tech: Started working low level hardware tech stuff with no degree. Realized I needed a degree to advance. It was obvious I should get a computer science degree.  Started that, realized I already knew a lot of CS, at least the basics.  Switched to get a math degree. I'm not the greatest mathematician, but it's a great credential.  Tech comes and goes, math is permanent.  Started programming and realized I could make better, more up to date systems.  Actively studied books from tech publishers, later online. Sometimes needed to remind managers that "people don't just magically wake up in the morning knowing how to use the latest tech", that part is not always obvious. This eventually lead to incredible freedom and flexibility in my job.  I always liked the learning part, was happiest when I didn't already know how to do something. commentText: My philosophical perspective is that the biggest trends in growth are dominated by means towards ends, which ends are being cut out of the equation, dominated by the tech sector. Advertising, AI, data analysis, marketing, content creation. But what all of these encompass are industries that fall within the category of what we would call *means* to some other end. Advertising advertises for a product. Where is the product? AI helps with aggregation and research: Research about what? Data analyzes data and marketing markets to increase sales: Selling what? Content creation creates content to generate money from attention either by subscription or monetization: Subscribing comes from willing subscribers who spend their time on this rather than having a barbeque or going out with a friend. Monetization is for, again, advertising. It is a world being sucked into digitization, a dystopia wherein public transportation is unbuilt, bridges depreciate, housing is built substandard or as lofts and multi-million speculation-housing that those already in the tech sector or finance or entertainment niches can buy. Nursing, medical staffing, retirement homes, education, childcare, parks, architecture, art, and basically everything life-giving or life-sustaining is exceedingly expensive yet underinvested, and depreciating rapidly.

commentText: I would say pursuing MBA after 5 years of hands on experience add immense value to your profile.  Reason is you have spent some good amount of time in your skillset and you understood thr market on what u wanna learn what u have to leave.   This clarity + pursuing MBA at top b school make you highly employed than others in the market. Since u alreadh know how job market works MBA add more skills of survival along with your experience. If in case you are extremely skillfull and experienced who doing MBA you might be ended up landing in finiest jobs.   Instead doing MBA jus after your graduation or just 2 years of industry experience doesn't help. Because the reason for people doing MBA is to enter manegerial role. Skills doesn't make you manage, but experience does. You can be a skillful employee. But you cant jus be a skillful manager. I would say spend 5 to 7 yesrs of your time in working and understand the market. Then move to MBA.  Special cases majority of the people do MBA for marriage profile. And pathetic is even a brides expecting MBA graduates as groom without realising that just a degree can't bring fortunes. The organisation is a fairly new set up and they need to get up to full capacity quickly in order to handle demand, so can't afford to waste time 2.  The organisation has lost key members of staff and need people to come in and steady the ship quickly 3.  It's a poor place to work and most other candidates have recognised that and not accepted job offers there, so they are virtually begging for candidates to come through the door 4.  They genuinely like you  1-3 are pretty common, 4 is really down to luck.  Market conditions also play a big role.  Right now, it feels like employers want people, but are too scared to commit budget, so they are waiting it out and hedging for a saturated job market for as long as they can.  Saturated job markets drive down salaries and benefits.  Under those conditions, candidates are going to be messed around.

Meanwhile, and while the next two have been the cycle of job market forever--it feels more rampant in this decade and probably forever but mass layoffs from all industries/verticals have seasoned professionals applying for entry-level jobs that are meant to be for these college grads, taking huge pay cuts just to survive, and employers are happy about that since they don't have to waste time training them and such. commentText: All these stories are enlightening. What I can't figure out is that so many people are driving what to me are very expensive cars (my 2006 Camry cost $4500 five years ago), getting huge houses (I had an 1100 sq ft house in a modest neighborhood ), going on vacations overseas and all - I've never had a vacation. I have a PhD (still unpaid for), & now rent a 320sq ft house in rural Arizona and very happy. But I must live very modestly. A meal at a coffee shop is a rare treat. Even coffee at a coffee shop is something I can only afford a couple days a week. Books a steady expense of course - my field is classical languages (Greek and Latin). Always the cheapest copies I can find on ebay or Amazon... Having a relationship a bit difficult because I have very little money, & my car's paint is pretty worn out and splotchy because of the endless sun beating on it. We must change this system. The values of a capitalist system. We are being robbed by the rich, folks. The system must go.

videoTitle: Ivy League Graduates Can't Find Jobs (JOB MARKET SUCKS)

commentText: While the job market is trash, an Ivy League diploma isn‚Äôt the stepping stone it once to an elite job‚Ä¶ with the main issues being:  1) Entitlement - Ivy League graduates believe they are worth way more than what the market is currently pricing. Graduates think that by getting a Columbia degree in Environmental Studies, this will set them up for a six figure salary out of the gate.  2) Expectation vs. Reality - In the past, employers hired Ivy League graduates expecting them to work harder and be more productive/inventive. In reality, they get a bunch of spoiled kids who complain about being overworked or underpaid. They also are statistically more likely to leave a job after a year‚Äîto chase higher salaries. Employers hate this because 6 months is usually the amount of time the company invests in you in order to train you.  3) Grade Inflation - The Ivy Leagues have all seen massive amount of grade inflation over the decade. While some argue this was exacerbated by DEI, grade inflation hurts the schools reputation and makes it harder for employers to distinguish the best from the average/mediocre. Simply maintaining a 3.5+ GPA means you probably partied more than you studied.  4) Automation - Many of the entry level grunt work is being automated out. Why pay an entry level coder or quant when AI can perform this work 10x faster and doesn‚Äôt come with a list of demands and complaints.

commentText: Over 80% of Chinese graduates can't find any kind of a job.  Many applicants don't realize that gaps in their work history only makes them ineligible for employment.  So do other things like a bad credit score, poor work history, lack of experience, unstable address history (aka, moving around too much) lack of reliable transportation, improperly dressed and groomed during an interview, not able to commit to the work schedule due to other priorities, not filling out the application truthfully or completely, etc..  Because you are competing against many other people for the same position, companies can afford to be very picky about who they hire, which is why you can fill out hundreds of applications and never once get a reply back.  If you are young and healthy, I would definitely consider either the military or the merchant marines as my next job consideration.

videoTitle: The Job Market Is Collapsing ‚Äî Even Harvard‚Äôs Best Graduates Can‚Äôt Find Work
videoDescription: The job market is collapsing, and even the most prestigious diplomas can't guarantee employment. In this video, we explore why ...
commentText: The main factor is that this is the beginning of a recession, and the first thing firms do is freeze new hiring, and that hits graduates hard.  The same thing happened to me, 30 years ago. I graduated with a civil engineering degree in 1992.  After looking for work unsuccessfully for a year, I offered to work for free to gain experience, but the bosses freaked out at that suggestion, saying it would demoralize their existing employees.  After doing BS work for a decade, I finally found the job I wanted in 2003. By then, there was such a severe shortage of civil engineers and technicians, that engineering firms were hiring anyone with a pulse.  The problem is there were no more graduates, because young people had got the message that there were no jobs for civil engineers, so were no longer entering into civil engineering programs.  I ended up doing work that I really wasn't yet qualified for, mainly because by then I was in my late 30s and bosses didn't realize how little experience I had, but fortunately I was able to learn fast, and it was a very steep learning curve. Within 5 years, I was the engineer in my department who was designing the largest, most complex and prestigious projects.

My entire professional career as well as personal life had be greatly delayed. I am no joke here. It was super frustrating back then, not only financially but psychologically as well. I have worked 17 years after college graduation, I have my up's and down's. And I think my past experience has greatly impact my personality today. I live a very frugal life saving most of my money and making investment and multiple passive income streams. Not married don't wanna have kids, and being humble all the times.  I don't know if this is good or bad.

commentText: If you go to an expensive college, you cut your chances of employment. You are too expensive. You need to start cheap in your field of work to gain experience for the next job. Then, you need to place the necessary  key words in your resume the employer is looking for. Take trips to the employer and get yourself noticed. Dress professional and ask questions. Get it known how much you would like to work there. If  you are not welcome don't go back.  Review the available jobs there. I solicited every job opportunity at my dream employer and sent multiple resumes and was eventually hired. Before the interview prepare for questions. One tricky question: What is your greatest weakness? Ex: I know I had micro managed employees in the past.  I have learned, with experience, how to best assign tasks based on the skillset of an employee and trust their independence and judgement. One answer may work on one interview, than not on another one. The important note is to be quick to respond with a reasonable answer! Turn a negative into a positive.

videoTitle: Even Harvard MBA Graduates Can't Get Jobs - THIS A RECESSION
videoDescription: In 2025, even people with master's degrees and higher credentials are struggling to secure meaningful work in a weakened job ...
commentText: I've done a top MBA in the last couple of years and lucky to get a good job (definitely a harder environment right now).  The drop in MBA hiring right now I think is explained by a couple of factors:  1) Downturn in hiring across some of the traditionally biggest recruiters - consulting firms (downturn with clients wanting to cut external spending in this environment), investment banks (higher rates, slower M&A environment), and tech (overall down sizing and potential structural issues from AI)  2) Market appears to be less "generalist friendly" - lots of MBAs are trying to pivot careers and frame themselves as generalists or "business swiss army knives" - I think this is true, and it can be useful, but with resume stacks on most recruiters desks really high right now, companies have the luxury of choice - why would you hire a smart career switcher with limited or no relevant experience over someone who has done the same job elsewhere? It's broadly not a time for companies to take serious risks and that's also showing in their hiring behaviours.

commentText: Currently in an M7 program and work in technology consulting. I will say from my 5 years of experience in my career and what im learning in my program, I think that MBA is still worth it. I have been surprised on projects that I work on how so many people with specialized skillsets lack the ability to lead, communicate, and make sound business decisions. Their specialized skillsets are valueable when it comes to innovating, but there is value in knowing how to lead a team to innovate efficiently, knowing where to reduce costs or expedite timelines, and making informed decisions backed by knowledge provided in an MBA curriculum. However, i will agree that it does ultimately depend on what your interests are and where you want to develop your career. If you want a position in leadership, want to be an entrepreneur, did an undergrad in STEM but pivoted into business and lack fundamental business knowledge, an MBA is most likely worth it for you.

Indeed, for those already employed, our results indicate AI is more likely to result in retraining than job loss," the economists said in a blog post on Thursday.  "That said, AI is influencing recruiting, with some firms scaling back hiring due to AI and some firms adding workers proficient in its use. Looking ahead, however, layoffs and reductions in hiring plans due to AI use are expected to increase, especially for workers with a college degree," they added.
